thread.title: TBS broadcasts of NLCS are only as good as their material
thread.title_full: TBS broadcasts of NLCS are only as good as their material - Chicago Tribune

author: Teddy Greenstein
title: TBS broadcasts of NLCS are only as good as their material
text:
It's tough to make lemonade with spoiled lemons. Or in the case of Game 2 of the NLCS, rotten eggs.
Nearly all of the action Sunday night came within 60 minutes of "60 Minutes."
That made for a boring game — excruciating, painful and boring for Cubs fans — and an understandably low-energy TBS telecast. Even the scene at Murphy's Bleachers after Kris Bryant's RBI double was ... meh.
You know you're getting a little desperate when you mention in the eighth inning, as Ernie Johnson did: "(Kyle) Schwarber has struck out three times tonight. But with one swing he can bring the Cubs within a run."
It was a contrast to what transpired Saturday night, when both Game 1 and TBS' coverage delivered.
Among the Game 1 highlights came when Johnson and ace (pun intended) analyst Ron Darling recounted a quirky conversation with Cubs skipper Joe Maddon.
Darling: "We talked about expensive honey, dark chocolate, Twizzlers."
Johnson: "The more we talked, the more we had in common, especially on the Twizzler front."
Darling: "Manuka honey, from New Zealand."
Johnson: "Really good if you're a little under the weather."
Darling made a strong point about the decision to send Starlin Castro, who got nailed by a Yoenis Cespedes throw: "You're down near the bottom of the lineup, I don't think that's a bad play by third-base coach Gary Jones. You don't get that many opportunities off these great pitchers."
And Darling joked of a Travis d'Arnaud blast that hit the giant red apple beyond center field: "D'Arnaud makes like skee ball ... 50 points!"
Johnson summoned his inner Jim Nantz at the top of Sunday's telecast, calling the apple shot "a home run that thrilled Mets fans to the core."
Johnson pointed out that Mets starter Noah Syndergaard had thrown 1,421 pitches of at least 95 mph during the season. That does sound incredible. But without any comparisons, who knows?
Darling said the Mets had learned crucial pitch patterns from Matt Harvey in Game 1 and would go heavy on breaking balls and changeups early in the count. Syndergaard promptly started Dexter Fowler with four straight fastballs.
Overall, though, Darling pounds the zone with strikes, as he did long ago with the Mets.
After Maddon instructed Jake Arrieta to walk Daniel Murphy, Darling said: "I'm shaking my head. ... I'll tell you right now: Arrieta wasn't intentionally walking anyone in the second half of the season."
Added fellow analyst Cal Ripken: "I don't think he wanted to there either."
The understated Ripken doesn't add a ton to the broadcasts, but he was in his wheelhouse analyzing a Curtis Granderson steal of second. Castro covered but could not apply the tag.
"That's a popular thing now with middle infielders," Ripken said. "Get in front of the bag, let the ball travel and reach back. I would still prefer the straddle of the bag. Gives you a better athletic position maybe to lean back and buy yourself some time to pick that and then put the tag straight down."
Ripken had a clever, if predictable, line in the top of the ninth. Mentioning the Mets closer, he said: "All I know is, we're getting very familiar with (Jeurys) Familia."
Johnson immediately responded: "Oh, you've been sitting on that one, Iron Man."
Johnson is an excellent play-by-plan man. His descriptions are crisp and accurate and he takes advantage of every opportunity to lighten the mood. In short, someone you'd want to sit next to for a three-hour game.
Just not this game, if you're a Cubs fan.
"The Mets take a 2-0 series lead," he said, "by beating Jake Arrieta."
A dagger to the heart.
